The Miami Open is turning into National Cake Week, with recent celebrations for Serena Williams' 700th career victory and Andy Murray's 500th victory. Williams advanced to the semi-finals with a 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 win over Sabine Lisicki, but was defeated by Carla Suarez Navarro in the next round. Despite this, Williams remains focused on advancing in what is her closest event. She will face either Sloane Stephens or Simona Halep in the final after defeating Lisicki and Halep advancing past Sloane Stephens.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani human rights activist and entrepreneur, was shot dead by gunmen in Karachi, Pakistan, after locking up her second-floor cafe on a dusty industrial road. She was known for her discussions on technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship, and her killing has sparked widespread grief and condemnation across the country. Mahmud had been advocating for free speech and had recently led a discussion group on topics related to separatist movements and human rights abuses in Baluchistan, which led to the cancellation of a planned event by the Lahore University of Management Sciences. Despite receiving death threats in the past for handling similar topics, Mahmud continued to host discussions in her cafe, making her a symbol of secular wisdom and a champion for free thought in Pakistan.

The passage discusses the plight of West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) in Indian Kashmir, who are unable to own property, vote in state elections, or hold government jobs due to their refugee status. Despite being in India, they are treated as second-class citizens in Indian Kashmir. The passage also mentions the hopes of Mangu Ram and other WPRs for change after the victory of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party in the Kashmir state elections.

The passage discusses forward Yoshinori Muto's consideration of joining Premier League leaders Chelsea this summer. Fc Tokyo President Naoki Ogane revealed that Chelsea has made an offer of around £4 million for the Japanese international. Muto, 22, is weighing his options, as he aims to join a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential. He is considering whether Chelsea's plan to loan him to partner club Vitesse Arnhem next season suits his needs. Muto values regular playing time and believes he can achieve his potential elsewhere. Real Zaragoza boss Ranko Popovic, who introduced Muto to Fc Tokyo in 2013, sees potential in the forward to excel at Chelsea, highlighting his intelligence, speed, strength, and confidence. Chelsea's Jose Mourinho is aware of Muto but has refrained from discussing him, acknowledging the club's focus on financial fairness and only signing good players or prospects.

The passage congratulates Australia for dropping the policy of not selecting their best overseas players, which it considers outdated and detrimental to the sport. It argues that England should adopt a similar policy, allowing Stuart Lancaster to select his best players regardless of their club affiliations. The passage highlights the success of players like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell playing for Toulon and criticizes England for not considering their best overseas players. It also mentions the improvement in players like Nick Abendanon and Jonny Wilkinson after they moved to France, suggesting that overseas players can enhance the English team. The author supports the idea of allowing players to play for whichever club makes them the happiest and healthiest, as it benefits the sport as a whole.

The passage discusses the development of the Greenstone device by Open Garden, which is designed to enhance off-the-grid networks created by the FireChat app. FireChat, which was developed to enable communication between friends without the need for the internet or mobile signal, uses a feature called MultiPeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) to create a wireless mesh network. This network connects phones to each other, allowing messages to be sent to people in close proximity using Bluetooth or Wi-Fi Direct, up to around 30 feet (9 meters).

Greenstone is an egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon or booster to help messages move around wireless mesh networks more easily. It is currently under development and only works with FireChat at a range of around 20 feet (6 meters). Once another FireChat device comes within range, the messages are passed on, and the device has a one-year battery life and can hold up to 1,000 of the most recent messages.

The potential applications for Greenstone include strengthening communication networks in communities, hospitals, or during events where large numbers of people can cause network crashes. Open Garden is currently working with manufacturers to design and sell Green

The passage discusses Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, who advocates for embracing the word 'fat' as an honest and body-positive description of her own physique. She compares 'fat' to other self-descriptors like'short' and 'wife', arguing that it doesn't have to be used as a synonym for 'ugly'. Bustle notes that society often discourages women from calling themselves 'fat', considering it the worst thing one can be. She points out that size discrimination in the workplace has increased by 66% in the past 30 years, and that negative perceptions of larger people start young, with the top'magic wish' for girls aged 11 to 17 being to be thinner.

Bustle highlights the positive impact of exposure to body diversity on people's attitudes, suggesting that the more we're exposed to different body types, the more we tolerate, accept, and prefer them. She uses her burlesque performances to expose her audiences to a 'fat' body in a positive and glamorous way, hoping to change perceptions. She also quotes another performer, Beelzebabe, who

The passage describes a familiar sight of Theo Walcott sitting on a bench with six Arsenal colleagues, indicating his lack of playing time due to being overlooked for the majority of the season. Walcott has been involved in a photoshoot with Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, Mesut Ozil, and runway model Olga Sherer for Lanvin, an official fashion house of Arsenal. The team's first-team players will wear similar attire for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30. Walcott has been named on Arsenal's substitutes' bench for 17 of their 33 Barclays Premier League games and came on for the last six minutes in a goalless draw with Chelsea. He is hoping to make his first Arsenal start since March 14 against West Ham when Arsenal faces Hull at the KC Stadium on Monday.

The passage discusses an upcoming auction of an amazing collection of props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker. The collection, which includes items from blockbuster films like Men in Black, Batman Forever, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas, will be auctioned off at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles, California, and on propstore.com on May 29. The collection is estimated to be worth $746,100, with some individual items expected to fetch over $40,000. Notable items from the collection include the Alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black, the Two Face mask from Batman Forever, the Grinch costume from How the Grinch Stole Christmas, and the Mikey costume from Men in Black. Baker's career spans over 30 years and has worked on films such as An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, Batman & Robin, Hellboy, and Mighty Joe Young. The auction is an opportunity for collectors and fans of Rick Baker and his work to acquire unique pieces from their favorite films.

Carwyn Scott-Howell, a seven-year-old British boy, tragically died in the French Alps after becoming separated from his mother during a skiing trip. The youngster, known for his daring, outgoing, and determined nature, was described as having a handsome smile that lit up any room. While skiing with his family, Carwyn ventured into dense woodland and fell over a 164 ft drop, leading to his untimely death. His body was eventually found by footprints in the snow, and a moving tribute from his family highlighted his positive impact on their lives and the joy he brought to their lives. Carwyn was a skilled skier and snowboarder who started skiing at the age of three. His family had spent a happy ski holiday together in the resort of Flaine before the tragedy occurred.

The passage is about a 15-year-old girl named Laura Scurr from Whitley Bay who suffered from anorexia nervosa, a serious mental health condition characterized by an intense fear of gaining weight, leading her to severely restrict her food intake and engage in unhealthy behaviors to lose weight. Laura's obsession with having a "perfect figure" led her to hide food, lie about eating, and survive on just one piece of fruit a day. Her dramatic weight loss resulted in her collapsing and being placed on a heart machine in intensive care. After recovering, Laura has spoken out about the pressures on young girls to be a size zero, and has been working with eating disorder teams and child and adolescent mental health services to help in her recovery. Today, she has made it to the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a competition aimed at promoting positive and confidence-building experiences for young girls, away from size zero stereotypes.

The passage discusses the unveiling of Liverpool's new home kit for the 2015/16 season, designed by sports brand New Balance. The kit was presented by Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet to fans at Annfield. The new design features a gingham pattern and is the first kit from New Balance to be used by Liverpool. The kit deal with New Balance is a record-breaking £300 million four-year contract, replacing Warrior as the club's suppliers. Fans were supportive of Raheem Sterling, who recently rejected a £100,000-a-week contract offer from Liverpool, and were keen to see him remain at the club. The players also expressed their hopes for success, particularly in the FA Cup, which they believe could be a platform for future achievements.

The passage discusses the creation of the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, produced by the University of Manchester. This map is the first in a series of maps that will provide a 3D view of dark matter across one-eighth of the night sky. The map allows astronomers to study how galaxies formed in the universe by revealing clumps of mystery particles across 0.4% of the sky. The goal is to eventually map 12.5% of the entire sky over five years, with red representing more dark matter and blue representing less. The map was created using data captured by the Dark Energy Camera, a 570-megapixel imaging device, and released at the April meeting of the American Physical Society. The survey uses the Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile to measure the shapes of galaxies, and the map was completed by 2018, mapping dark matter of an eighth of the sky. Understanding the clumpiness of dark matter over time will reveal the nature of the mysterious dark energy, which is the ultimate goal of the survey.

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay, a 21-year-old winger. Manager Louis van Gaal is keen to make Depay one of his first signings this summer, having previously named him in his 23-man World Cup squad in 2014, where Holland finished third. Van Gaal is familiar with Depay's qualities, having played a significant role in the Dutch national team's success during the 2014 World Cup. Depay has been in impressive form this season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games for PSV, helping the team win the Dutch championship. He has also been linked with moves to other top European clubs, including Paris-Saint Germain, despite PSV's technical director stating that Depay is now worth more than the £15 million offered by Tottenham last summer.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory over Manchester City's young side in Manchester, with Tammy Abraham scoring a double and Dominic Solanke adding a third goal. The match saw appearances from several young Chelsea players, including Dominic Solanke, Tammy Abraham, Tosin Adarabioyo, Cameron Humphreys-Grant, and Fikayo Tomori, who formed a strong partnership in defense. Manchester City's young players also showcased their skills, with Kean Bryan, Isaac Buckley-Ricketts, Brandon Barker, and Manuel Garcia participating in the match.

Marco Rubio believes that people are born with a sexual preference, but he does not believe that same-sex marriage should be a constitutional right. He suggests that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman, and that states should regulate marriage. Rubio would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, but does not agree with same-sex marriage being a constitutional right.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are a couple who have quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to embark on a global cycling adventure. They are traveling across the world by bike, aiming to discover different parts of the planet. They are doing it as cheaply as possible, relying on free accommodation, such as through hosting websites, and occasionally dumpster diving for food. So far, they have covered almost 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) and visited 16 countries. They plan to continue their journey into Asia, across the Pacific, and eventually cycle the length of the American continent.

The passage describes a couple from Texas who experienced a wedding photo incident in 2012. The couple hired a photographer named James Evans, who owns the company Premier Photos. During the wedding, a photo booth printed racial slurs on some of the photos, specifically saying "poor n ***** party." The couple was not informed of the issue until much later, when their sister-in-law revealed the incident. The couple's attorney, Cathy Hale, stated that the bride's sister initially decided not to inform the couple about the photo booth's content to avoid ruining the bride's special day.

The couple is now suing Premier Photos under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence, breach of contract, and seeking an apology. The lawsuit stems from the couple's belief that Premier Photos was responsible for the offensive content printed on the photos. James Evans, the owner of Premier Photos, denies all allegations and claims there is no evidence linking his company to the offensive caption. The case is set for trial in July, with mediation scheduled for the following day. The couple's attorney emphasizes that the lawsuit is not about money, but rather seeking an apology from James Evans.

Mike Brown is recovering from his latest concussion setback and adopting a cautious approach to ensure a safe return to action. He remains unsure of his return date after pulling out of a match against Saracens. Northampton Wing George North has been advised by medics not to play again this season after suffering four concussions. Ireland's Johnny Sexton was previously stood down for 12 weeks due to a concussion. Brown's concussion occurred after England's victory over Italy in the RBS 6 Nations, and he was treated by the England medical team. Brown credits increased awareness of concussion symptoms, driven by rugby players completing online modules, for his decision to withdraw from the Ireland match. He emphasizes the importance of honesty and the seriousness of concussions, urging teammates not to push through symptoms.

Smartphone use may be contributing to a decrease in the frequency of sexual activity among couples in Britain, according to a leading expert, Professor David Spiegelhalter. Research has shown that the number of times heterosexual couples are having sex each month has been declining since the emergence of the internet. Professor Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, noted in his book "Sex by Numbers" that the typical couple now has sex three times a month, down from five times in 1990 and four times in 2000. He attributed this decline to the integration of public and private lives, with people constantly checking emails and the increased technological connectivity eroding boundaries between home, work, and the outside world. This has led to a decrease in quiet empty time, making it harder for couples to prioritize intimacy and sex.

Tibetan mastiffs, once valued at up to £1.2 million each due to their association with corruption and status in China, are now facing extinction as they are being sent to slaughterhouses and their meat is being used in cheap hotpots. The decline in their popularity is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has reduced the demand for them as gifts, and recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several Chinese cities. Additionally, the breed's popularity has been impacted by the increasing urbanization and the deterioration of the breed's quality for financial gain, leading to a surplus of poor-quality dogs that cannot be sold.

The passage discusses a survey conducted in Paris where every woman surveyed claimed to have experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport. Half of the respondents were assaulted before the age of 18. The poll led to calls for a campaign to address sexist or threatening behavior on buses and trains. The survey found that all female users of public transport have experienced gender harassment or sexual assault, despite some being unaware due to conditioning. The harassment can range from insults to more serious actions like insistent flirting, whistling, comments on appearance, sex attacks, or rape. The problem is such that six out of ten women are afraid of being attacked on public transport compared to three out of ten men. The survey highlighted the limitations on women's freedom due to these attacks, forcing them to change their daily routines and behaviors to avoid confrontation. The high council for gender equality, which compiled the report, called for women to be able to move freely and safely in public spaces without fear of harassment. The council emphasized the need for better education and awareness among both aggressors and witnesses to address the issue of sexual harassment on public transport.

The passage describes a competition called #everydayfix organized by Direct Line, a Leeds-based company, which invites groups to design products aimed at addressing common everyday emergencies such as forgetting to lock the door, losing keys, or running out of battery on your phone. Participants in the competition include a forget me lock prototype designed to remind users if they have locked their front door, an alarm clock called "Snooze" that silences phone notifications to promote better sleep, and the world's smallest mobile phone charger, "Nipper." These products were designed as part of the Direct Line Everyday Fix design makeathon, where people were asked to rank their top ten "everyday emergencies." The competition is funded through a Kickstarter campaign, and the winning product will be developed into an actual product.

A police crime commissioner named Vera Baird gave £500,000 to a charity called Victims First Northumbria, which helps people who have been affected by crime. Vera is also a director of this charity. Her partner, Sue Sim, who is the chief constable of Northumbria, is also involved with the charity. Because of this, some people think it's not right and accuse them of making decisions that seem like a TV show. The Ministry of Justice is now looking into the situation to see if there was any wrongdoing.

The passage describes a horrific assault on a 53-year-old man by a group known as the 'Tattoo Terrorists'. The ringleader, Corry 'Corey' Campbell, 21, and his accomplices, Sandra Ng, 19, and Carl Halin, 18, tortured the victim, Greg Valecce, by beating, tying him to a chair, and tattooing offensive symbols on his body. Valecce was also accused of hurting Campbell's pet cat, Pebbles, which had a broken leg. The assault lasted for three days, and the group filmed the abuse. Valecce managed to escape and report the incident to the police. The group was charged with aggravated assault, conspiracy, and false imprisonment, and all pleaded guilty. Campbell, Ng, and Halin were sentenced to prison, with Campbell receiving 20 years and Ng and Halin receiving the same sentence for their actions against Valecce. Thomas and Pratt are awaiting sentencing and trial, respectively.

Manager Louis van Gaal is keen to make Depay one of his first signings this summer, having previously named him in his 23-man World Cup squad in 2014, where Holland finished third. Van Gaal is familiar with Depay's qualities, having played a significant role in the Dutch national team's success during the 2014 World Cup. Depay has been in impressive form for PSV, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games this season, and has been compared to Dutch star Arjen Robben and Cristiano Ronaldo.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are a couple who have quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to embark on a global cycling adventure. They have no plans, agenda, or cause to fight for and are taking it slow, covering 16 countries and almost 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) in 356 days so far. They are living on less than three euros each per day, relying on free accommodation, such as through hosting websites, and their bicycles for transport. Their diet consists of pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal fruits, and vegetables, with occasional wild fruit and dumpster diving in Western countries. Their journey has taken them from London to Turkey, across the northern coast of Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, and into Georgia, with plans to continue into Asia and across the Pacific.

Smartphone use may be contributing to a decline in the frequency of sex among couples, according to a leading expert, Professor David Spiegelhalter. Research has shown that the number of times Britons have sex each month has been decreasing since the rise of the internet. Professor Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, noted in his book "Sex by Numbers" that typical heterosexual couples now have sex three times a month, down from five times a month in 1990 and four times a month in 2000. He attributes this decline to the integration of public and private lives, with people constantly checking emails and the increased busyness of life due to better technological connections eroding boundaries between home, work, and the outside world.
